stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, can you explain how capnography works and interpret a capnograph trace?

prompts.text: Describe the principles of capnography measurement.
expectedKeyFacts: Measures partial pressure of CO₂ in respiratory gases
Infrared spectroscopy — CO₂ absorbs infrared light at 4.3 μm
Beer-Lambert law: absorption proportional to concentration
Mainstream: sensor in breathing circuit, fast response, no sampling delay
Sidestream: gas sampled via thin tube, slower response, risk of blockage
Normal ETCO₂: 4.5-6.0 kPa (34-45 mmHg)
Difference between PaCO₂ and ETCO₂ normally <1 kPa

prompts.text: Describe the phases of a normal capnograph trace.
expectedKeyFacts: Phase 0 (inspiratory baseline): zero CO₂ — inspiratory gas
Phase I (expiratory upstroke): rapid rise — anatomical dead space washed out
Phase II (expiratory upstroke): steep rise — mixed dead space and alveolar gas
Phase III (alveolar plateau): gradual rise — alveolar gas, slope reflects V/Q matching
End-tidal point: peak of phase III
Phase IV: rapid fall during inspiration

prompts.text: What would cause a gradual decrease in ETCO₂ during anaesthesia?
expectedKeyFacts: Decreased cardiac output: reduced pulmonary blood flow → less CO₂ delivered
Hypothermia: reduced metabolic rate → less CO₂ production
Hyperventilation: excess alveolar ventilation → lower alveolar CO₂
Air embolism: increased dead space
Circuit disconnection or leak: dilution with room air
Inadequate CO₂ production: prolonged anaesthesia, muscle relaxation
Pulmonary embolus: sudden fall with V/Q mismatch

prompts.text: You see a sudden fall in ETCO₂ to near zero during laparoscopic surgery. What are the possible causes and how would you respond?
expectedKeyFacts: Differential diagnosis: cardiac arrest, massive pulmonary embolus, circuit disconnection, oesophageal intubation (if recent)
Check patient: pulse, BP, ECG — exclude cardiac arrest
Check breathing circuit: connections, ventilator functioning
Auscultate chest: bilateral air entry
CO₂ embolism in laparoscopy: gas insufflation → venous embolus
Management of CO₂ embolus: stop insufflation, 100% oxygen, left lateral head-down position, supportive measures
Cardiac arrest: start CPR immediately
Document and investigate cause

prompts.text: Why might the gradient between PaCO₂ and ETCO₂ be increased?
expectedKeyFacts: Normal gradient <1 kPa — reflects alveolar dead space
Increased V/Q mismatch: COPD, pulmonary embolus
Increased dead space: air embolism, low cardiac output
ETCO₂ underestimates PaCO₂
Rapid shallow breathing: inadequate alveolar plateau
In healthy lungs with normal cardiac output, gradient minimal
Cannot rely on ETCO₂ as surrogate for PaCO₂ in diseased lungs
Arterial blood gas needed for accurate PaCO₂ in sick patients

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me what you would see on the capnograph if the endotracheal tube was in the oesophagus — what would the trace look like?
keyFacts: Phases: 0 (inspiratory), I (dead space), II (mixed), III (alveolar plateau)
Decreased ETCO₂: low cardiac output, hyperventilation, embolus, disconnection
Sudden fall to zero: arrest, massive PE, disconnection
Increased gradient: V/Q mismatch, dead space, low CO

scoringGuidance.pass: Explains infrared spectroscopy and Beer-Lambert law, describes capnograph phases correctly, interprets changes in ETCO₂ with differential diagnosis, recognises significance of sudden fall and gradient changes; stronger candidates discuss mainstream vs sidestream and V/Q physiology
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows capnography measures CO₂ but mechanism unclear, can identify some phases but interpretation vague, mentions some causes of changes but non-systematic
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot explain measurement principle, does not understand capnograph trace, unaware of clinical significance of ETCO₂ changes, no differential for sudden fall
